commentBody: Was this for me? No, it was FIR YEW. Ouch! Nice present from David Kwong. Happy to see rebuses on the tree, even if their locations were given away. Now I'm going back to junior high school, when I read about the TETROMINO (and the other polyominoes) in Martin Gardener's column in "Scientific American" (one of the dozens of magazines I read because my dad the ad exec received comp copies).

My wrong headed mutterings while solving:

‚ÄúOh, AOKI is the rebus here, it must be a golf theme?‚Äù (nope, that was the OAK)

‚ÄúClarence Darrow‚Äù (uttered out loud several times, unable to see the CEDAR for the trees)

‚ÄúCan u feel my fire‚Äù and various other as-yet unused song titles.

In short, a fun puzzling time! Hope it was as fun FIR YEW as it was for me! (Hi Barry.)

After their day at the beech, kind planters remember to say "trees" and "thank yews."

(They arbor no resentment.)
Thanks for the holiday gift. This puzzle was enjoyable. I was happy with it. "Orange" you glad too?

What a delightful Christmas present!  Clever, challenging and so much fun figuring out each rebus tree. I caught on with CLAREN(CEDAR)ROW. 

Fabulous clue for ASH WEDNESDAY [Fast start?].

I learned a new word today, TETROMINO. 

Great debut of Fleetwood Mac's classic RHIANNON and fun fact that she was a Celtic goddess. 

Thanks, David! I just knew a puzzle by you would never be a lemon.

Great holiday puzzle üéÑüéÅ Loved seeing RHIANNON in the puzzle. My cousin was named after the song ‚ò∫Ô∏è https://youtu.be/0xGPi-Al3zQ?si=KANevk6JVGhhJcrQ Nice start to this week. Thank you, David.

Late last year (12/15/24) David Kwong gave us "Art Heist," which turned out to be the winner of the Sunday category in the 2024 Griddies. It was also the most controversial and most commented-upon (a whopping 1536 comments), the top one being from Paul in NY, who began, "Did not love it. I think it was technically interesting...But i think the mechanics of solving it sucked the life out of it. Meaning...that having to search the clue list to find which Across had a word needed for a Down just was tedious and wasn't any fun." 571 people gave that comment a thumbs up. And yet it won the Sunday category of the Griddies. Go figure. Link to Art Heist: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2024/12/15 This one is not as complex, not as much a tour-de-force and I don't expect it to garner near the hue and cry as Art Heist. Liked the PALM OFF AS, since I'm sure Mr. Kwong has palmed many a card in his life, and maybe other things too. Tetromino was cool. At first I had Fat Domino, figuring maybe Fats was nicknamed after a particular kind of domino tile. What do I know? Also liked Amanda Gorman sharing space with Zora Neale Hurston and Eryka Badu, all three top wordsmiths, and the overall richness of the fill, lots of character with shrink ray, ski planes, chitter, Clarence Darrow, frothing, the lovely Prelude to a Kiss, Rhiannon, Can't Feel My Face, (this puzzle has its own soundtrack), and especially the trio of Skate Rats, Get Over It and Transepts! POY material?
I bet my DOGWOOD enjoy this puzzle. I did.

Wow, just wow. Everyone complaining about how easy the last two days were just got their due.
Was going to say this was going to be the most polarizing puzzle since Art Heist, and then I look at the byline.
On the one hand, this is really a constructor‚Äôs puzzle. You have to admire the artistry of the construction, imagine finding entries with all the trees, symmetrical, with letters underneath that spell FIR YEW‚Äîit really was a magic trick. Did I enjoy it? Absolutely, it was tailor made for my brain even though I had to be dragged kicking and screaming every inch. That includes the end where I had to flyspeck five times before seeing I misspelled TRAN(C)EPTS. So many fun tricky clues I can‚Äôt list them. I mean, it‚Äôs absolutely brilliant.
But also let‚Äôs admit it won‚Äôt be accessible to many solvers. To get there, most of the long downs had to be proper names or titles‚Äîwhile not obscure per se then at least hard to get if you don‚Äôt know them. And if you don‚Äôt know them pulling the rebuses from the crossings will be like pulling a rabbit out of a hat. And then the rest of the fill was just not forgiving. BAMA AMIR AMANDA BADU crossing ARNOLD PALMERS, admit it, that‚Äôs gonna be pretty brutal for a lot of people, and that wasn‚Äôt the only inaccessible spot.
So, again, this was absolutely my kind of puzzle and I had an absolutely blast‚Äîwhat a Christmas gift. But I won‚Äôt be giving any Grinches a hard time because they  also have a point.
Wait are some of the answers wrong on purpose I feel like Im missing something here. I got a few answers that are missing letters, or is that just me?

Fir the life of me, I can't figure out why my rather enthusiastic response to this puzzle has been twice emued. Can't see a single thing in it that could possibly be caught in the filters. Sigh. I know I used a lot of exclamation marks but they've never emued me for that before. Well, I guess I'll try it thrice now. 
--
Oh, fir fun!! That's probably way too Minnesotan a thing for most of yew, but it's a phrase I learned upon moving here, only spelled fer. There's also "Oh fer cute!" ü§£ Oh, how I do love Minnesotans. 

Anyhow, all I can say is I was bopping around the grid thinking that this one was pretty D-RN hard but when I got the trick, I found myself with the biggest smile! Hurray!! A rebus, I practically squealed!!! Oh fir fun!!!!! 

This one, at least for me, was difficult, about 20% slower than average, but it was so sparkly and delightful and oh so clever! 

I sometimes wish they wouldn't show where the rebuses will be found but I liked it this time because of the FIR YEW, which is oh fir cute, fir sure! 

And I hear that 118A is still moo-ing!!

Got seriously tripped up in the NE, and I must vociferously protest 3D. Tennis line judges do not rule balls in, either verbally or through hand signals. They only rule balls out. They are not TV commentators who might shout "It's in!" on a down the line winner. The answer makes no sense in response to the clue.

I had fault in there for the longest time and refused to remove it until I came up with SKIPLANES, since no other appropriate word could have worked for 3D, including what was used for the correct answer

One question though: how is DOM "Counterpart of a sub" in 16D? 

That's the only one I didn't get. I mean, I got it on the crosses but found myself not getting why. 

Any help?
A fun challenge for a Saturday night. Today's "where's the rebus?" challenge was an interesting twist.
Very fine.  Once I filled in 69 Down, the puzzle quickly surrendered.

I loved it. I print it out, which sometimes gives me a different rebus experience (so I gather) from the online crowd. Grateful for the instruction about the "letters" in the circles and reading them left to right, so I knew the circle would contain just one letter, despite my urge to put the rebus there (which of course failed instantly, as Caitlin said, for "rebranded," etc.). I also loved how unusual it was to have the free-floating rebuses NOT in the circle AND of different lengths. A real treat! Thanks, David!
Great puzzle today, very challenging. Had to use the column to help with some clues. Still, very fun.

Great puzzle, thanks, David. Quite the feat of construction and linguistic legerdemain.

I, for one, appreciated the indicators for the rebus squares, which is usually quite a frustrating challenge as a newer solver. The fact that I didn't get that until I had 4 of 6 done is completely irrelevant. 

Did get hung up a bit in the top center, though - three crossing proper names and I was unfamiliar with all of them, anchored by the Mediterranean flowers that I was also not familiar with. 

Still, a very enjoyable solve!

What a fun puzzle that was, Mr. Kwong! And great to see you‚Äôre a total nerd who loves crosswords and magic puzzles! Hope your daughter continues to inspire you to come up with more creative puzzles! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Fun Sunday! More challenging than most in recent memory, but never to the point of pain. My only truly uncertain crossings when the dust settled where RHIANNON + RITA (I guessed the R because nothing else sounded right for _ITA) and KEANE with ANIL (again, just got lucky that N sounded the best). 

Most delightful example of the rebus trick, for me, was DANCED AROUND crossing CLARENCE DARROW. Just a Herculean feat!

The puzzle was tough to solve, when it seemed to me that the circles ought to contain a rebus and didn't, but I could see, again and again, that something was a little off.  Some of CLARENCE was there, but no room for DARROW, and knew ELMO was for sailors, and it fit just fine, but in the end it didn't until a saw the ST.

I finally noticed that the rebus squares contained woods, but by then I had them all in anyway, just because the letters were the only ones that made sense.

David Kwong, this was a now-you-see-it-now-you-don't magical puzzle, and I needed to do look-ups for names I didn't know and to confirm the spelling of the ones I did. It was harder for me than your art heist creation all those months ago (which I  r e e a a l l y  liked a lot!) but I did enjoy it, and thank you.

I wonder what you'll have up your sleeve next time.
Great puzzle except for ANIL and TETROMINO. What?!

I enjoyed the main theme, one of the "Fun to discover" ones.  I got most of the way through then got really hung up on a few corners.

I'd never heard of TRANSCEPTS or the term SKATERATS, and I still don't see how the heck PETIT is an answer for the 'Four' clue.

Then the conjunction of MASSE/MENLO was a 100% Natick for me, and also don't know the word ELIDES and found YESYES awkwardly phrased for that clue.

Then took me forever to figure out it was TETROMINO and not TETRAMINO considering "TETRA" is the prefix for four.

Most of the puzzle was super fun though.

If I wasn‚Äôt clear in my earlier post, I WILL OWe you an apology, I hoPE A Repost will help. This was far froM A PLEasure cruise to solve but I have neither bitterness nOR ANGEr about the difficulty‚Äîit was sO LIVEly and and its artistry made me want to clAP‚ÄîPLEnty of clever, misdirecting clues that were sure to curB ANY ANimosity I might have felt.  I only have epic LOVE for this puzzle. If you disagree, I won‚Äôt use any fanCY PRESSure tactics to change your mind but I can‚Äôt get enough of puzzles like this, I guess I‚Äôm just an enigMA HOG‚ÄîANYone agree?

Like many things in life, didn't get all of it, but sure did love what I got. Anothe fine bit of DK shenamigans. Now it's time to lift that stylus on the dusty turntable and just melt away into the evening . . . now you see me . . . now y

If you can't see
(Was it yew or me?)
Like an olive crying
For it's gin
That was this grid
David lulled you in
A prelude to a miss!

So you feared no rebus win
Used your shrinkray on roots that grewin  
OOH! Dave (a card-sharp) planting word sins
Old man, getoverit!

Though it's just a simple remedy
Illusion with seed
Nothing much
He could turn it to a simple tree
A conjurer with a verdant touch!
The TETROMINO/SOO cross got me. (I should have said ‚ÄúTETROMINO‚Äù out loud to myself.) Well played, David.
Very cute so far!  I will finish in the morning.

Remarkable puzzle. Bravo.

Terrible editorial decision to attach credit for solving it to filling in the circles from the clue on the title page. Seriously? Such a disadvantage for online solvers. Boo.
Fantastic! The final reveal and the complexity to pull it all off together was stunning

A direct result of going to Costco often was reading 16D ‚ÄòCounterpart of a sub‚Äô & entering DOg. Seemed reasonable at the time. I held onto it until the end. 

Really good fun! Thanks David. I loved SCHEMATA. I appreciate Fir and Yew making it in.
I guess I don‚Äôt play enough Monopoly, this one had me stumped. I tried basically every letter for 56A, and I screamed when I got it! Very tough puzzle for me, but a fun rebus nonetheless.
Rebus (AKA another Sunday puzzle ruined).

Wow, seven days of gold stars! Fun theme! SODA SHOP is what got me there. So many brain busters for me, and red Herrings, and I had to put all my faith into leaving ANIL alone, but it all fell together in two hours.

I was my own worst enemy solving this one. William Jennings Bryan would not get out of my head so I could remember CLARENCE DARROW, plus I had a few other things wrong over in thar area, and I spelled TRANSEPTS wrong. Ugh, flyspecking. But overall a fine Sunday challenge from Mr Kwong. I think it's pretty safe to say that if you see a clue that references Phillipa and and singing and Broadway and is three letters, the answer is going to be SOO. Ms SOO played the Schuyler sister, Eliza, who marries Hamilton in that musical. Here she is with her sisters. https://youtu.be/POHVE9uCNAY?si=7mZEp2siAmiG2tWC

Well done, Mr Kwong! I admire the work of most constructors, but every now and then I am in awe. I wasn‚Äôt surprised to be reminded that David Kwong also created the infamous Art Heist puzzle. Although it won POY last year (deservedly so IMO) it sent the drama department into such a tizzy that to this day whenever someone mentions Art Heist I could swear I hear the theme music from Jaws. How nice that today we get Prelude to a Kiss instead.
Rebus puzzle ‚Äî my favorite kind of Christmas present! It being above the circle threw me off until I got to the revealer in the bottom right corner. Loved it, thanks for the fun solve!
Perfect, pre Christmas puzzle. Just the right amount of challenge and clever theme!

I was pretty unhappy with BAMA and AMIR crossing BADU, AMANDA, and ARNOLD, but someone has already pointed that out as a likely complaint, so I'll move on.

Moving on ...
How is NINER allowed without some hint in the clue that it's a shortening, or at least informal? I'm no sports fan, and know almost nothing about NFL teams beyond the names, but even I know that there's no team called the NINERs, so I think the clue isn't following the rules.
Ruh-roh, the Brits are going to have trouble with the Monopoly properties.  The yellows are entirely different in their game.
i think im starting to get when people say that the lack of difficulty was made up for by the degree of delight.

Oh, fir fun!! That's probably way too MN niche an ism for most of yew, but it's a phrase I learned upon moving here. There's also "Oh fer cute!" ü§£ Oh, I do love my adopted home state!  

All I can say is I was rumbling around to and fro on here thinking that this one was pretty DARN hard but when the poor bygone penny dropped, I found myself with the biggest smile!  Hurray!! A rebus, I practically squealed!!! Oh fir fun!!!!! 

This one, at least for me, was on the hard side... about 20% slower than average, but it was sparkly and delightful and oh so clever! 

I sometimes wish they wouldn't give where the rebuses will be found but I liked it this time because of the FIR YEW, which is oh fir cute, fir sure! 

118A is definitely still mooing!!

Anyhow, all I can say is I was bopping around on here thinking that this one was pretty DARN hard but when the poor bygone penny dropped, I found myself with the biggest smile! 

Hurray!! A rebus, I practically squealed!!! Oh fir fun!!!!! 

This one, at least for me, was on the hard side... about 20% slower than average, but it was sparkly and delightful and oh so clever! I sometimes wish they wouldn't give where the rebuses will be found but I liked it this time because of the FIR YEW, which is oh fir cute, fir sure! 

And I hear that 118A is definitely still mooing!!

Mr. Kwong asks if I found the irregularities difficult.  Yes, but I was sort of on the right track.  After the revealer, I found 5 of the 6 trees.  But I didn't figure out where to put the rebuses with the extra letters.  So I read checked the puzzle to find out.

I enjoyed the puzzle, but was a bit perplexed by the FIR YEW meta-theme. When I read the letters, from left to right, I get WEIYFR. I get it. That‚Äôs an anagram that gives you the punning FIR YEW. But I‚Äôm only surprised it wasn‚Äôt clued as an anagram. Or did I missing something in reading those letters?

A truly impressive puzzle! It took me slightly longer than my Sunday average (around an hour) and had to look up a couple of things (Monopoly, as many others have mentioned, is pretty well-regionalised) but what fun when it all came together! Also had to laugh that the last rebus I figured out was to complete my own surname

I really liked this puzzle. It was hard, in particular, the northeast. That quadrant fell one slow letter after another. Then, yikes! Rebuses!  But, it was such fun that they were all trees creating little smiles along the way. 

The payoff at the end was that there was no running the alphabet and zero flyspecking. It doubles my satisfaction to finish clean.

I recently stumbled on a puzzle that I had somehow missed about a year ago.  A little puzzle called "Art Heist".

One way or another, "Art Heist" isn't a puzzle you're not going to remember.  

Anyway, I noted the name Kwong at the time.

Cut to present, I thought this was a devious, utterly wacky puzzle, and now I see it's Mr. Kwong come to rattle me timbers once again.

Well done, Mr. Kwong.

Not my favorite.

I would still really encourage the NYT editors to come up with a better way to indicate that a rebus is a part of the puzzle other than having to go to the solvers notes article to confirm that this is the case.

In his show, ‚ÄúThe Enigmatist,‚Äù David Kwong constructs a crossword in real time, right in front of his audience. I‚Äôm not sure how genuine it is (he is a magician, after all), but the effect is dazzling. For those who haven‚Äôt had the pleasure of seeing his show, here‚Äôs a clip: https://youtu.be/U1VPUZDr-fY

the visual/hiding/sleight-of-hand element in mr kwongs puzzles really makes him a standout constructor, in my limited experience.
i adored the art heist, i daresay the most divisive puzzle ive ever encountered in the wordplay column over the eight months or so ive lurked and contributed here.
his is the first constructor name i am unlikely to forget.

Nice one! I have stopped racing the clock so i can really enjoy the puzzles, and I really liked the slow reveal on this one. Figured out it had to be a rebus by about a quarter way down, started filling them in in the circles.. 
And so forth. A couple name-crossings, but not undoable. Thanks!

Life‚Äôs a beech, and then you do this puzzle.

Great fun! I enjoyed the magic tricks, too.

Theme was begrudgingly fun, even coming from someone who is pretty grinchy about Christmas being everywhere all the time. 

Just means I can pass my annoyance onto the unreal number of proper nouns and naticks.

I liked the theme & this should have been fun to work out. The antics and worse trivia with rebuses spoilt it, as in looking up the inaccessible trivia, the rebus is revealed.

Note to editors: rap and jazz are niches. If you listen to it you know otherwise it's just word salad. Ditto plays, films, directors, authors. I look it up and don't get ahah, but instead who? what?

Excellent puzzle. No surprise it comes from the brilliant creator of the Art Heist puzzle, which I remember very fondly. 

Well, I‚Äôm off to get the last of the Xmas gifts, then help pack up the car to take off tomorrow for parts subarctic. I‚Äôm happy we have family in Europe, but how I wish sometimes my forebears had come from, say, Tahiti, and not places you drive to with 4-wheel-drive engaged‚Äîand mostly in the dark. 

Have a good Sunday, everyone.
My only issue with rebus-es is that we haven't come up with a better name for them.
The puzzle was fine and the rebuses were okay but the circled letters....eh....

Very fun puzzle! I didn't understand the circled squares until it was spelled out in the column, shoulda written it down. Loved the rebuses being before the circled letters, because that added some suspense.

16D being DOM is pretty racy for the Gray Lady. 14A took me a while, then as I filled that in thought noooo... Now where were my pearls??

Took for absolutely ever. ü´§ 

Way too much trivia for my taste. The BAMA BADU AMANDA AMIR block went way beyond the natick. It was cruel. 

The gimmick was ok and cleverly executed. STELMO should have sufficed but it took UNDERTHETREE to get me there. 

Tomorrow‚Äôs another day. 

Thanks.

Several years ago, @Andrew (Ottawa) dubbed David ‚ÄúKing Kwong,‚Äù and he has lived up to that billing once again. I was one of those solvers who found this to be a challenging Sunday, even though I cottoned to the theme pretty early.  The northwest especially slowed me down between TETROMINO and IT‚ÄôS IN, and whiffing on my familiar crossword nemesis ANIL.

Speaking of @Andrew, his 2018 Wordplay take on ‚ÄúThe Night Before Christmas‚Äù was itself magical.  While many of the Wordplayers referenced in his magnificent poem no longer appear in this forum or only post occasionally, his final stanza remains quite timely:

In case you have noticed I've missed one or two,
(They're the ones that can make this place less (more?) of a zoo).
They're a mixture of wit, wisdom, knowledge and chutzpah
Though occasionally known to drive us quite nuts - yeah! (OK that rhyme sucked...)
The pair I refer to, I'm sure you can tell
Are the trusty home team of BA and Steve L.
If I've been self-effacing, and maybe unduly,
From Canada's capital I am yours truly.
There are others galore but I've run out of space
I am grateful to all who inhabit this place.

So to all you who help me get through the long week,
Merry Christmas to all, and to all a long streak!
TETROMINO crossing SOO‚Ä¶

This really did feel like a gift from David Kwong to me. There's just something about this type of rebus that tickles my brain.

I saw the rebus early on with PRELUDE TO A KISS, but since they were all different, I still had to figure out what each one was, which is always enjoyable.  Since they worked both ways, it was double the fun.

If I had the opportunity to make one change, I would have omitted the circles in the grid.  I see from David's notes that the Games Team wanted that.  Part of the fun is figuring out *where* the rebus goes, so as soon as I got one, I knew where the rest were.  Maybe hints like that should be optional?

I want to focus on UNDER THE TREE, a phrase known to all, and one lending itself so perfectly to a crossword theme presented just as in today‚Äôs puzzle.  Yet it has never been done before, in any of the major crossword outlets.  Kudos to David, for plucking this out of the ether.

Then there‚Äôs the emotion packed into that phrase, part of that magical feeling of Christmas.  Uncovering UNDER THE TREE kindled that feeling and flooded me with memories.  

I remember when our son Jordan was five, how he nervously looked at the meager few presents under the tree before he went to sleep on Christmas Eve, and then when he raced out of bed in the morning and saw the sea of presents spreading out. He looked at us with wide eyes and exclaimed, ‚ÄúMommy! Daddy! That Santa Claus is a VERY NICE MAN!‚Äù

Loved your puzzle on many levels, David.  Thank you so much for this!‚Äù

Barclay, James got nothin‚Äô on this baby!

Fir yew anil.
TIL so many new things. What a fun-filled puzzle.

A rebus where the extra letters aren't in the circles (and the circles almost weren't in the puzzle at all!)....after slowly trekking through this I'm not sure whether the constructor should be permanently hired or never allowed to make another puzzle ever again. Possibly both? Bravo sir.

Ever Since Darwin would have been nice with Clarence Darrow. 

Surprisingly, I haven‚Äôt read that book yet. Evolution is a favorite subject of mine. Perhaps Santa will leave it under the tree.

I‚Äôm currently reading Your Inner Fish by Neil Shubin. Dr. Shubin is a paleontologist and was a member of the team that discovered the famous Tiktaalik fossil. His insights on how we retain characteristics of our fishy ancestors is fascinating.

Other recent reads I‚Äôll recommend‚Ä¶
The Greatest Show On Earth by Richard Dawkins
The Rise And Fall Of Dinosaurs and
The Rise And Reign Of Mammals both by Stephen Brusatte
Wow‚Äîneat puzzle! It sure felt good when I figured out the twist. Not sure why it took me so long to get that first rebus, but after that, the rest fell right into place.

This was not fun at all. The theme was okay, nothing too great. Not having the rebus in the circle was weird but the indicator gave us that hint.

But the fill was so UGH inducing that for the first time in 1.5 years I did not feel like even trying to complete the top right and center areas. I just clicked on reveal puzzle and didn't read the answers because I don't even want to know. That is the level of boredom I had with this puzzle.
67A betrays a wholesale lack of knowledge about its topic, which is radio signals.
LOVED.  I wish every Sunday was like this.

As a gardener I enjoyed this arboreal puzzle, although I kept trying to put the rebuses in the circles even after I‚Äôd figured out that the circles were under the trees.  Sadly that confirms once again that I am a slave to habit.  I caught on to the trick initially at the great Duke Ellington song PRELUDET(OAK)ISS and had fun searching the forest for the trees.

As a lawyer I was happy to see the renowned CLAREN(CEDAR)ROW spotlighted (spotlit?) in the themed clues.  While Darrow enjoys a deserved stellar reputation for his representation of John Scopes and other prominent figures, his legacy is complex, as he was twice charged with attempted jury bribery, and may well have engaged in that practice more frequently than is generally known.  There‚Äôs a fine history of the case against labor leader Bill Hayward called Big Trouble by Anthony Lukas, which paints a vivid picture of life in the United States (and Idaho in particular) in the first decade of the 21st century as seen through the labor movement. Clarence Darrow features prominently as Hayward‚Äôs lawyer, and baseball icon, Walter ‚ÄúBig Train‚Äù Johnson is part of the narrative too.

Abbreviation not found on most smartphones? 

Is this seriously a clue?


Could just have easily been "4 letters found in the alphabet" or "I dunno, just guess from the crosses"

I got the rebus part of it fairly quickly, as well as the revealer, but sure had a devil of a time filling in some of those trees, such as CEDAR, into the tiny boxes on my paper grid, even with my ultra fine point pen!

Two answers that slowed me down that were totally out of my wheelhouse were CAESAR cipher and TETROMINO, even though I was a Tetris addict way back then. Never heard the word then or now. And I had to read almost all the way to the end of the comments to get the explanation for 6D, DOM. I guess I never heard the terms abbreviated before. Also never heard of SKATE RATS, but since I knew of gym rats and mall rats, I figured out that the ending for SKATE had to be RATS.

At least I was able to complete it without having to resort to lookups, unlike the Art Heist puzzle, which I despised and totally gave up on. So even though I got all the trees and the revealer without too much trouble, I finally gave up trying to figure out what the circles spelled out. I was just grateful that this was the first Sunday puzzle in a month that I didn't have to use a magnifying glass to see the numbers, so as soon as I filled in the last letter, I tried to get the punny answer but quickly gave up. 

This was indeed a master of construction. I can't say I loved it, and I'm not sure why. But I do recognize the brilliance.

That was tough! The trick was cute and i managed to get a few of the themed entries but even having gotten CEDAR from DANCE AROUND didn't help me since I didnt know CLARENCE DARROW. Didn't know ARNOLD PALMERS either. I wish so many of the themed answers weren't proper nouns/trivia related. Gave up at some point and just revealed the final bits. Not my favourite Sunday.

I loved this puzzle.  I was waiting for a Christmas themed, chunky butter spread, with some smoothness.  

For those that struggled, it takes time to learn all of the NYT puzzle tricks.  Be patient with yourself and the constructor.  

NYT is not about speed runs - although with everyone talking about their times I can see where there‚Äôs pressure. 

Thanks King Kwong!!
Delicious.  I don't rush through dessert or puzzles.  Enjoyed the impressive challenge.

This was a lovely, fun puzzle, a frolic in a rebus forest.
Thanks for the magic, David Kwong!



I got tripped up a bit in reading 7D. Who has ever said 51 to the hour?
But in Baltimore, it's 6:42.
Wow. A tour de force (and also fun). "Clarence Darrow" crossing with "danced around"? Amazing.

Loved this puzzle! Had SOCKHOP instead of SODASHOP, but it didn't fit, so I knew it contained a rebus element right away. Led me to realize the rebus was above the circle. From the title my original guess on the revealer was "down the chimney."  I was off to the races with ARNOLD PALMER, my favorite NA beverage (try adding a little Bourbon for a great cocktail). Loved Art Heist, needed the circles, love David Kwong. Thank you for a fun Sunday.
That was just *fab.* Bravo David Kwong!
Brilliant and fun! Really enjoyed this.
I really hate when there‚Äôs a rhombus. You can‚Äôt type that in on your phone. I ended up skipping the puzzle.

Perhaps the regular editorial team was on holiday and the Grinch filled in?

Perhaps the worst Sunday puzzle I can recall. Torturous, in so many ways.

It is worth noting that a significant number of the gripes about Art Heist had to do with the interface of the puzzle. In the puzzle, there are pairs of clues: for example 8A is [*Painting stolen from 71-Across*], and 71A is [Common scale range]. The referring clue significantly helps solving the other.

Normally when there are related clues, the corresponding clue(s)/answer(s) are highlighted. When it was first published, when solving 71A, 8A wasn't highlighted. This left it to the solver to keep track of all the pairs of clues, for seemingly no reason.

It has since been updated to properly highlight the paired clues, but I wonder what feedback it would have initially gotten if it was published with the standard clueing interface.

Some people are still grumpy about it a year (and maybe years) later!

That was so long ago that it was called a word-cross puzzle, not a crossword. https://www.businessinsider.com/first-crossword-puzzle-that-ran-100-years-ago-2013-12 The first NYT puzzle, on 1/15/42, looked more like a modern crossword, started off with a proper name at 1A and included several others. https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=2/15/1942 Disallowing names makes it inordinately difficult for a constructor to create a decent puzzle. @Francis I ran across this in my search for enlightenment: "Green paint" is shorthand for a multi-word entry, usually in the form of ADJECTIVE NOUN, which has no meaning beyond the literal "a NOUN which is ADJECTIVE"; such entries are usually frowned upon in crossword puzzles. For example, RED FLAG could be clued as [Warning sign], and BLACK FLAG could be clued as ["TV Party" band], but you'd be hard-pressed to find a clue for ORANGE FLAG beyond... um... [Thing that waves in the air and is the color between red and yellow]. The term was invented back in 2004 by Patrick Berry, who in his Crossword Constructor's Handbook (https://aframegames.com/store/?download=21) calls out GREEN PAINT as an example of the sort of technically-a-thing entry lesser constructors might cobble together in a grid, noting that "it's [hard] to conjure up a hypothetical reference work that would bother to list GREEN PAINT." Ironically, several constructors have put GREEN PAINT in puzzles clued in reference to Berry's terminology, meaning the entry GREEN PAINT is not green paint.
